Beamforming and Device Selection Design in Federated Learning with Over-the-air Aggregation

Faeze Moradi Kalarde⋆⋆\star, Min Dong††\dagger, Ben Liang⋆⋆\star, Yahia A. Eldemerdash Ahmed‡‡\ddagger, Ho Ting Cheng‡‡\ddagger ⋆⋆\starUniversity of Toronto††\daggerOntario Tech University‡‡\ddaggerEricsson Canada
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) with over-the-air computation can efficiently utilize the communication bandwidth but is susceptible to analog aggregation error. Excluding those devices with weak channel conditions can reduce the aggregation error, but it also limits the amount of local training data for FL, which can reduce the training convergence rate. In this work, we jointly design uplink receiver beamforming and device selection for over-the-air FL over time-varying wireless channels to maximize the training convergence rate. We reformulate this stochastic optimization problem into a mixed-integer program using an upper bound on the global training loss over communication rounds. We then propose a Greedy Spatial Device Selection (GSDS) approach, which uses a sequential procedure to select devices based on a measure capturing both the channel strength and the channel correlation to the selected devices. We show that given the selected devices, the receiver beamforming optimization problem is equivalent to downlink single-group multicast beamforming. To reduce the computational complexity, we also propose an Alternating-optimization-based Device Selection and Beamforming (ADSBF) approach, which solves the receiver beamforming and device selection subproblems alternatingly. In particular, despite the device selection being an integer problem, we are able to develop an efficient algorithm to find its optimal solution. Simulation results with real-world image classification demonstrate that our proposed methods achieve faster convergence with significantly lower computational complexity than existing alternatives. Furthermore, although ADSBF shows marginally inferior performance to GSDS, it offers the advantage of lower computational complexity when the number of devices is large.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, over-the-air computation, device selection, receiver beamforming.

I INTRODUCTION

Fe derated learning (FL) is an effective distributed machine learning technique that allows multiple devices to collaboratively learn a global model using their local datasets [1, 2]. A parameter server needs to aggregate the local model updates from the devices to perform a global model update. However, in wireless FL, information exchange between the devices and the server can create stress on the limited communication resources, especially when a substantial number of devices participate in the process. In such a scenario, the devices may not be able to send their updates simultaneously via conventional orthogonal multiple access over the limited available bandwidth.

In order to improve communication efficiency in wireless FL, analog aggregation of the local models has been proposed [3]. In this approach, the devices simultaneously transmit their local models using analog modulation over a shared wireless uplink channel, which naturally results in model aggregation at the receiver by superposition. Such over-the-air computation has attracted growing interest due to its advantages of efficient utilization of bandwidth and reduced communication latency over the conventional approach of orthogonal multiple access [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10].

However, over-the-air computation is susceptible to noise, which can cause significant aggregation errors that propagate over the FL computation and communication iterations. Furthermore, the quality of aggregation is disproportionately affected by devices with weak channel conditions, since the devices with strong channel conditions have to reduce their transmit power in order to align their transmitted signal amplitude with that of devices experiencing weak channels. This adjustment leads to a lower received signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) [2]. Although excluding devices with weak channels can reduce the aggregation error, it can also harm the learning performance as a result of the reduced size of training data. Therefore, we need to carefully design an effective method for device selection that can properly trade off these two effects to improve the overall FL training performance.

Device selection for over-the-air FL was first considered in [3] and later in [11] and [12]. In [3], a distance-based device selection method within a cell was proposed to increase the received SNR at the base station (BS). In [11], the authors proposed to only select the devices with strong channel conditions in the learning process to improve the convergence of the model training. However, how to design a proper threshold on the channel strength for device selection was not discussed. In [12], under imperfect downlink channel conditions for model broadcasting, device selection and transmit power at both devices and the server were jointly optimized to minimize the global training loss. All these works assume a single antenna at the server for communication, and thus the multi-antenna receiver processing was not considered.

In current wireless networks, the server is typically equipped with multiple antennas, where beamforming techniques can be applied to enhance the signal strength and reduce the noise in over-the-air computation [13, 14]. It has been demonstrated in [15] that the method in [14] can be applied to improve FL performance. However, the study in [15] did not consider device selection. In [16], joint receiver beamforming and device selection were considered to maximize the number of selected devices while limiting the communication error, where a difference-of-convex-function (DC) programming method was proposed to solve the joint optimization problem. For the same problem considered in [16], the authors of [17] introduced a low-complexity method to design the receiver beamforming and device selection jointly. However, the design objective of maximizing the number of selected devices in [16] and [17] does not explicitly measure the impact of device selection and communication error on FL training performance. FL via a reflective intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted wireless system was considered in [18], where device selection, receiver beamforming, and RIS phase shift were jointly considered to minimize an upper bound on the steady-state expected global loss as the training time approaches infinity. In their proposed scheme, the successive convex approximation (SCA) method is used to design receiver beamforming, and Gibbs sampling is used for device selection. However, their design and analysis assume fixed wireless channels over time for all communication rounds of FL. Furthermore, the computational complexity of Gibbs sampling is high, especially as the number of devices increases, which is not desirable when device selection needs to be updated in each communication round.

In this work, we consider FL with over-the-air aggregation. Aiming at improving the training convergence rate for FL, we jointly design uplink receiver beamforming and device selection to minimize the global training loss after arbitrary T𝑇T communication rounds, subject to per-device average transmit power constraint. Unlike existing works, we formulate our design problem assuming the wireless channel is time-varying over communication rounds, and the device selection and beamforming solutions are computed in each round based on the current channel state information. The main contribution of this paper is summarized as follows:

  • •

    The formulated joint receiver beamforming and device selection problem is a challenging finite time-horizon stochastic optimization problem. By analyzing the training procedure, we obtain an upper bound for the global training loss function after T𝑇T communication rounds. To improve the convergence rate of FL, we design receiver beamforming and device selection to minimize this upper bound on the global loss.

  • •

    The reformulated joint optimization problem is a mixed-integer programming problem that presents significant challenges. We first propose a Greedy Spatial Device Selection (GSDS) approach to obtain a solution. GSDS uses a greedy method to select the devices and then solves the corresponding beamforming optimization problem among the selected devices. In particular, GSDS uses a sequential procedure to add devices to the set of selected devices based on a metric that measures the channel strength and the channel correlation to the selected devices. Given the selected devices, we show that the optimization problem with respect to (w.r.t.) receiver beamforming is equivalent to downlink single-group multicast beamforming, for which we apply an SCA method to obtain a solution. The overall computational complexity of GSDS is shown to grow with the number of devices M𝑀M as 𝒪​(M3)𝒪superscript𝑀3\mathcal{O}(M^{3}).

  • •

    To reduce the computational complexity, we further devise an Alternating-optimization-based Device Selection and Beamforming (ADSBF) approach. ADSBF employs the alternating optimization technique to break the joint optimization problem into two subproblems w.r.t. receiver beamforming and device selection and solve them alternatingly. We show that the receiver beamforming subproblem is the same as that in GSDS and can be solved in the same manner. For the device selection subproblem, despite being an integer problem that generally is difficult to solve, we are able to develop an efficient algorithm in our problem to find the optimal solution with computational complexity 𝒪​(M2)𝒪superscript𝑀2\mathcal{O}(M^{2}).

  • •

    We test the proposed GSDS and ADSBF with real-world image classification tasks using MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. Our simulation results demonstrate that both GSDS and ADSBF outperform existing methods for beamforming and device selection design in terms of the training convergence rate. They also have significantly lower computational complexity compared with the existing methods. This shows the effectiveness of our proposed approaches in providing a proper trade-off between the impact of noisy communication and the amount of training data. Between the two approaches, GSDS performs slightly better than ADSBF as it leads to faster convergence. However, the run time of ADSBF is significantly lower than that of GSDS when the number of devices is large.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we present the system model and problem formulation for over-the-air FL. In Section III, we reformulate the problem via training convergence analysis. In Section IV, we propose GSDS and ADSBF approaches to obtain the solution. The simulation result is provided in Section V, followed by the conclusion in Section VI.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

II-A FL System

We consider a wireless network consisting of a server and M𝑀M local devices. The set of the devices is denoted by ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. Device m𝑚m has a local training dataset of size Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m} and denoted by 𝒟m={(𝐱m,k,ym,k):1≤k≤Km}subscript𝒟𝑚conditional-setsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑘subscript𝑦𝑚𝑘1𝑘subscript𝐾𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m}=\{(\mathbf{x}_{m,k},y_{m,k}):1\leq k\leq K_{m}\}, where 𝐱m,k∈ℝbsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑘superscriptℝ𝑏\mathbf{x}_{m,k}\in\mathbb{R}^{b} is the k𝑘k-th data feature vector, and ym,ksubscript𝑦𝑚𝑘y_{m,k} is its corresponding label. The devices aim to collaboratively train a global model at the server that can predict the true labels of data feature vectors from all devices while keeping their local datasets private. The empirical local training loss function at device m𝑚m is defined as

Fm​(𝐰;𝒟m)≜1Km​∑k=1Kml​(𝐰;𝐱m,k,ym,k),≜subscript𝐹𝑚𝐰subscript𝒟𝑚1subscript𝐾𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑚𝑙𝐰subscript𝐱𝑚𝑘subscript𝑦𝑚𝑘\displaystyle F_{m}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{m})\triangleq\frac{1}{K_{m}}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K_{m}}l(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{m,k},y_{m,k}), (1)

where 𝐰∈ℝD𝐰superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} is the global model parameter vector, and l​(⋅)𝑙⋅l(\cdot) is the sample-wise training loss function associated with each data sample. The global training loss function is defined as the weighted sum of the local loss functions over all devices, given by

F​(𝐰)=1K​∑m=1MKm​Fm​(𝐰;𝒟m),𝐹𝐰1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝐹𝑚𝐰subscript𝒟𝑚\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{m=1}^{M}K_{m}F_{m}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{m}), (2)

where K=∑m=1MKm𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑚K=\sum_{m=1}^{M}K_{m} is the total number of training samples over all devices.

We follow the general Federated Stochastic Gradient Descent (FedSGD) approach for the iterative model training in FL, where the server updates the global model parameters based on an aggregation of the gradients of all devices’ local loss functions [19]. The learning objective is to find the optimal global model 𝐰⋆superscript𝐰⋆\mathbf{w}^{\star} that minimizes the global training loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}). We call each iteration of the global model update a communication round. In communication round t𝑡t, the following steps are performed:

  1. 1.

    Device selection: The server selects a subset of devices to contribute to the training of the model. The set of selected devices in round t𝑡t is denoted by ℳts⊆ℳsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡sℳ\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}}\subseteq\mathcal{M}.

  2. 2.

    Downlink phase: The server broadcasts the model parameter vector 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} to all devices and notifies the selected devices.

  3. 3.

    Local Gradient computation: Each selected device m𝑚m computes the gradient of its local loss function, given by 𝐠m,t=∇Fm​(𝐰t;𝒟m)subscript𝐠𝑚𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑚subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝒟𝑚\mathbf{g}_{m,t}=\nabla F_{m}(\mathbf{w}_{t};\mathcal{D}_{m}), where ∇Fm​(𝐰t;𝒟m)∇subscript𝐹𝑚subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝒟𝑚\nabla F_{m}(\mathbf{w}_{t};\mathcal{D}_{m}) is the gradient of Fm​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑚⋅F_{m}(\cdot) at 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}.

  4. 4.

    Uplink phase: The selected devices send their local gradients to the server through their uplink wireless channels.

  5. 5.

    Global model update: The server computes a weighted aggregation of local gradients to update the global model. In the ideal scenario where the local gradients can be received at the server accurately, the weighted aggregation 𝐫t≜∑m∈ℳtsKm​𝐠m,t∈ℝD≜subscript𝐫𝑡subscript𝑚superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡ssubscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝐠𝑚𝑡superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{r}_{t}\triangleq\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}}}K_{m}\mathbf{g}_{m,t}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} is used to update 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\bf w}_{t}. However, in practice, the received complex base-band signal processed at the server 𝐫^t∈ℂDsubscript^𝐫𝑡superscriptℂ𝐷\mathbf{\hat{r}}_{t}\in\mathbb{C}^{D} is imperfect due to the noisy communication channels. Thus, the server updates the global model as

    𝐰t+1=𝐰t−λ∑m∈ℳtsKm​ℜ⁡[𝐫^t],subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡𝜆subscript𝑚superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡ssubscript𝐾𝑚subscript^𝐫𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\frac{\lambda}{\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}}}K_{m}}\Re[{\mathbf{\hat{r}}_{t}}], (3)

    where λ𝜆\lambda is the learning rate, and ℜ⁡[⋅]⋅\Re[\cdot] represents the real part of a complex variable.

II-B FL with Over-the-Air Analog Aggregation

We assume the server is equipped with N𝑁N antennas, and each device has a single antenna. The uplink channel between device m𝑚m and the server in communication round t𝑡t is denoted by 𝐡m,t∈ℂNsubscript𝐡𝑚𝑡superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{h}_{m,t}\in\mathbb{C}^{N}. We consider over-the-air analog aggregation over the multiple access channel to efficiently obtain the aggregated local gradients at the server [3]. The FL system with over-the-air aggregation is shown in Fig. 1. In each communication round, the devices send their local gradients to the server simultaneously over the same frequency band. Due to the superposition of the transmitted signals, the server receives the weighted sum of local gradients.

At each communication round t𝑡t, the local gradient of each selected device is transmitted over D𝐷D channel uses (or symbol durations). Specifically, the local gradient vector 𝐠m,tsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m,t} at the selected device m𝑚m is first normalized by its local gradient normalization scalar vm,tsubscript𝑣𝑚𝑡v_{m,t}, and then adjusted by the transmit weight am,t∈Csubscript𝑎𝑚𝑡𝐶a_{m,t}\in C for transmission. Thus, the transmitted signal for the d𝑑d-th entry of the local gradient gm,t​[d]subscript𝑔𝑚𝑡delimited-[]𝑑g_{m,t}[d], which is denoted by qm,t​[d]subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡delimited-[]𝑑q_{m,t}[d], is given by

qm,t​[d]=am,t​gm,t​[d]vm,t.subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑎𝑚𝑡subscript𝑔𝑚𝑡delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑣𝑚𝑡\displaystyle q_{m,t}[d]=a_{m,t}\frac{g_{m,t}[d]}{v_{m,t}}. (4)

To facilitate the receiver processing at the server, each selected device m𝑚m sends its local gradient normalization scalar vm,t=‖𝐠m,t‖Dsubscript𝑣𝑚𝑡normsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡𝐷v_{m,t}=\frac{\|\mathbf{g}_{m,t}\|}{\sqrt{D}} via the uplink signaling channel to facilitate the receiver processing. We assume the signaling channel is a separate digital channel and the reception is perfect.

Let 𝐪m,t=[qm,t​[1],…,qm,t​[D]]Tsubscript𝐪𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑡delimited-[]1…subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡delimited-[]𝐷𝑇\mathbf{q}_{m,t}=[q_{m,t}[1],...,q_{m,t}[D]]^{T} denote the corresponding transmitted signal vector for 𝐠m,tsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m,t}. From (4), the average transmit power used to send each entry in 𝐠m,tsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m,t} from device m𝑚m in communication round t𝑡t is ‖𝐪m,t‖2D=|am,t|2superscriptnormsubscript𝐪𝑚𝑡2𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑡2\frac{\|\mathbf{q}_{m,t}\|^{2}}{D}=|a_{m,t}|^{2}. The average transmit power is subject to the maximum average transmit power limit P0subscript𝑃0P_{0}: |am,t|2≤P0superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑡2subscript𝑃0|a_{m,t}|^{2}\leq P_{0}, ∀m,∀tfor-all𝑚for-all𝑡\forall m,\forall t.

The corresponding received signal at the server for the d𝑑d-th channel use is given by

𝐲d,t=∑m∈ℳts𝐡m,t​qm,t​[d]+𝐧d,t,subscript𝐲𝑑𝑡subscript𝑚superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡ssubscript𝐡𝑚𝑡subscript𝑞𝑚𝑡delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝐧𝑑𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{y}_{d,t}=\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}}}\mathbf{h}_{m,t}q_{m,t}[d]+\mathbf{n}_{d,t}, (5)

where 𝐧d,t∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,σn2​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐧𝑑𝑡𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2𝐈\mathbf{n}_{d,t}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\sigma_{n}^{2}\mathbf{I}) is the receiver additive white Gaussian noise for the d𝑑d-th channel use and is i.i.d. over t𝑡t.

The server applies receive beamforming to process the received signal. Let 𝐟t∈ℂNsubscript𝐟𝑡superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbf{f}_{t}\in\mathbb{C}^{N} denote the receive beamforming vector in communication round t𝑡t with ‖𝐟t‖=1normsubscript𝐟𝑡1\|\mathbf{f}_{t}\|=1, and let ηt∈ℝ+subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptℝ\eta_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{+} denote the receive scaling factor. The server uses the real part of the post-processed signal ℜ⁡[𝐫^t]subscript^𝐫𝑡\Re[{\mathbf{\hat{r}}_{t}}], which contains the received local gradients from the selected devices to update the global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\bf w}_{t} based on (3).111Note that for more efficient transmission, 𝐠m,tsubscript𝐠𝑚𝑡\mathbf{g}_{m,t} can be sent via complex signals using both the real and imaginary parts of the signal. The receiver can perform post-processing to extract information from the real and imaginary parts of the received signal. In this work, we only consider information being sent using a real-valued signal for simplicity. This will not change the fundamental process developed subsequently.

II-C Problem Formulation

Since learning efficiency is crucial for FL, we aim to maximize the training convergence rate. As such, our objective is to minimize the expected global loss function after T𝑇T communication rounds by jointly optimizing the device selection ℳtssuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡s\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}}, the devices transmit weights {am,t}subscript𝑎𝑚𝑡\{a_{m,t}\}, and the receiver processing (beamforming vector 𝐟tsubscript𝐟𝑡\mathbf{f}_{t} and scaling factor ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t}). This optimization problem is formulated as follows:

min{𝐟t,𝐬t,ηt,{am,t}}t=0T−1subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐟𝑡subscript𝐬𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝑎𝑚𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\displaystyle\min_{\{\mathbf{f}_{t},\mathbf{s}_{t},\eta_{t},\{a_{m,t}\}\}_{t=0}^{T-1}}\quad 𝔼​[F​(𝐰T)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑇\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{T})] (7)
s.t. |am,t|2≤P0,∀m,∀t,superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑡2subscript𝑃0for-all𝑚for-all𝑡\displaystyle|a_{m,t}|^{2}\leq P_{0},\>\forall m,\forall t, (8)
‖𝐟t‖=1,∀t,normsubscript𝐟𝑡1for-all𝑡\displaystyle\|\mathbf{f}_{t}\|=1,\forall t, (9)
ηt>0,∀t,subscript𝜂𝑡0for-all𝑡\displaystyle\eta_{t}>0,\forall t, (10)
𝐬t∈{0,1}M,∀t,subscript𝐬𝑡superscript01𝑀for-all𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{s}_{t}\in\{0,1\}^{M},\forall t, (11)

where 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}[\cdot] is the expectation taken over the receiver noise, and 𝐬tsubscript𝐬𝑡\mathbf{s}_{t} is the binary device selection vector at round t𝑡t, with its m𝑚m-th entry st​[m]=1subscript𝑠𝑡delimited-[]𝑚1s_{t}[m]=1 indicating device m𝑚m is selected to participate the model updating in communication round t𝑡t and 00 otherwise. Note that 𝐬tsubscript𝐬𝑡\mathbf{s}_{t} and ℳtssuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡s\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}} convey the same information, and we have ℳts={m:st​[m]=1,m∈ℳ}superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡sconditional-set𝑚formulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑡delimited-[]𝑚1𝑚ℳ\mathcal{M}_{t}^{\text{s}}=\{m:{s}_{t}[m]=1,m\in\mathcal{M}\}.

III Problem Reformulation Based on Global Training Loss Analysis

Problem (7) is a finite time horizon stochastic optimization problem, and the global loss function in the objective is not an explicit function of the optimization variables. Moreover, it is a mixed integer program. To tackle this challenging problem, we consider a more tractable upper bound on the loss function through training loss convergence analysis and propose our algorithm to minimize this upper bound.

III-A Upper Bound on the Global Training Loss

To analyze the expression of F​(𝐰T)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑇F(\mathbf{w}_{T}), we rewrite the global model update at the server in (3) as

𝐰t+1=𝐰t−λ​(∇F​(𝐰t)+𝐞t),subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡𝜆∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐞𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\lambda(\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\mathbf{e}_{t}), (12)

where ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is the gradient of global loss function at 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}, and 𝐞tsubscript𝐞𝑡\mathbf{e}_{t} is the error vector representing the deviation of the updating direction from ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Based on (3), the error vector 𝐞tsubscript𝐞𝑡\mathbf{e}_{t} can be expressed as follows:

where the first component of the error 𝐞1,tsubscript𝐞1𝑡\mathbf{e}_{1,t} arises from the difference between the accurate aggregation 𝐫tsubscript𝐫𝑡\mathbf{r}_{t} and its server-estimated counterpart ℜ⁡[𝕣^t]subscript^𝕣𝑡\Re{[\hat{\mathbb{r}}_{t}]}, due to imperfect communication, stemming from receiver noise and analog aggregation across wireless channels. The second component of the error 𝐞2,tsubscript𝐞2𝑡\mathbf{e}_{2,t} is due to the subset selection of devices. When all devices are chosen, this term disappears.

From (II-B), 𝕣^tsubscript^𝕣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{r}}_{t} is a function of the selected devices, the transmit weight {am,t}subscript𝑎𝑚𝑡\{a_{m,t}\} at these devices, the receive beamforming 𝐟tsubscript𝐟𝑡\mathbf{f}_{t}, and the receive scaling ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} at the server. Given selected devices set ℳtssuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡𝑠{\cal M}_{t}^{s} and receive beamforming 𝐟tsubscript𝐟𝑡\mathbf{f}_{t}, we want to optimize the receive scaling ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} and transmit weight {am,t}subscript𝑎𝑚𝑡\{a_{m,t}\} to minimize the expected error 𝔼​[‖𝐞1,t‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝐞1𝑡2\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{e}_{1,t}\|^{2}] under the transmit power constraint (8), which is given by

s.t. |am,t|2≤P0,∀m,superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑡2subscript𝑃0for-all𝑚\displaystyle|a_{m,t}|^{2}\leq P_{0},\>\forall m, (15)

An error expression similar to (III-A) is analyzed in [18] for an RIS-assisted FL system, where an upper bound on the expected global loss function 𝔼​[F​(𝐰t+1)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})] is derived. III-B Problem Reformulation via Training Loss Upper Bound

Note that minimizing 𝔼​[F​(𝐰T)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑇\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{T})] in (7) is equivalent to minimizing 𝔼​[F​(𝐰T)−F​(𝐰⋆)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰⋆\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{T})-F(\mathbf{w}^{\star})]. However, 𝔼​[F​(𝐰T)−F​(𝐰⋆)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑇𝐹superscript𝐰⋆\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{T})-F(\mathbf{w}^{\star})] is difficult to optimize directly. Instead, we minimize its upper bound in (III-A). Note that since ψtsubscript𝜓𝑡\psi_{t} is an increasing function of d​(𝐟t,𝐬t;ℋt)𝑑subscript𝐟𝑡subscript𝐬𝑡subscriptℋ𝑡d(\mathbf{f}_{t},\mathbf{s}_{t};\mathcal{H}_{t}), the upper bound in (III-A) is an increasing function of d​(𝐟t,𝐬t;ℋt)𝑑subscript𝐟𝑡subscript𝐬𝑡subscriptℋ𝑡d(\mathbf{f}_{t},\mathbf{s}_{t};\mathcal{H}_{t}), t=0,…,T−1𝑡0…𝑇1t=0,\ldots,{T-1}. Thus, to minimize the upper bound, it is sufficient to minimize d​(𝐟t,𝐬t;ℋt)𝑑subscript𝐟𝑡subscript𝐬𝑡subscriptℋ𝑡d(\mathbf{f}_{t},\mathbf{s}_{t};\mathcal{H}_{t}) at each round t𝑡t w.r.t. (𝐟t,𝐬t)subscript𝐟𝑡subscript𝐬𝑡(\mathbf{f}_{t},\mathbf{s}_{t}). This joint device selection and receiver beamforming optimization problem is given below, where we drop subscript t𝑡t from the problem for notation simplicity:

min𝐟,𝐬subscript𝐟𝐬\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{f},\mathbf{s}}\quad d​(𝐟,𝐬;ℋ)𝑑𝐟𝐬ℋ\displaystyle d(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{s;\mathcal{H}}) (25)
s.t. ‖𝐟‖=1,norm𝐟1\displaystyle\quad\|\mathbf{f}\|=1, (26)
𝐬∈{0,1}M.𝐬superscript01𝑀\displaystyle\quad\mathbf{s}\in\{0,1\}^{M}. (27)

IV Joint Device Selection and Receiver Beamforming with Analog Aggregation

The joint device selection and receive beamforming problem (25) is a mixed-integer program and is challenging to solve. Below, we propose two approaches to find a solution. The first approach uses a greedy method to select the devices based on their channel strength and correlation and then solves the corresponding beamforming optimization problem. To reduce the computational complexity, we further propose an alternating-optimization-based approach, where we devise an efficient low-complexity algorithm for the sub-problem of device selection.

IV-A Greedy Spatial Device Selection (GSDS) Approach

From (III-A), we note that the channels of the selected devices, in both their strength and correlation among each other, can affect the value of d​(𝐟,𝐬;ℋ)𝑑𝐟𝐬ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{s;\mathcal{H}}). Specifically, d​(𝐟,𝐬;ℋ)𝑑𝐟𝐬ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{s;\mathcal{H}}) is a decreasing function of the channel strength of each selected device. Furthermore, since the same receive beamforming vector 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} applies to the channels of all selected devices, having highly correlated channels among these devices improves the minimum beamforming gain among them, which leads to a reduced value of d​(𝐟,𝐬;ℋ)𝑑𝐟𝐬ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{s;\mathcal{H}}). Based on these two factors, we propose a Greedy Spatial Device Selection (GSDS) approach. It uses a sequential procedure to add a device to the set of selected devices. We use a metric to measure channel strength and its correlation to the set of selected devices. In each step, the device with the maximum metric value is added to the set of selected devices, and then beamforming optimization is performed for (25) under this new set of selected devices. Since the beamforming optimization is performed in each step, we first describe this beamforming design problem, and then detail the device selection procedure for GSDS.

IV-A1 Receiver Beamforming Design Given Device Selection

Assume the current set of selected devices is given by 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} (or equivalently ℳssuperscriptℳs{\cal M}^{\text{s}}). Problem (25) is now reduced to the receiver beamforming optimization problem w.r.t. 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} at the server. Since the first term of d​(𝐟,𝐬;ℋ)𝑑𝐟𝐬ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{s;\mathcal{H}}) in (III-A) is a function of 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} only, with given 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}, problem (25) is equivalent to

min𝐟subscript𝐟\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{f}} maxm∈ℳs⁡Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2subscript𝑚superscriptℳssuperscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2\displaystyle\max_{m\in{\cal M}^{\text{s}}}\frac{K_{m}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}} (28)
s.t.‖𝐟‖=1.s.t.norm𝐟1\displaystyle\textrm{s.t.}\quad\|\mathbf{f}\|=1. (29)

By introducing the auxiliary variable c𝑐c, we can further rewrite the min-max problem (28) as its equivalent epigraph form as

min𝐟,c𝐟𝑐min\displaystyle\underset{\mathbf{f},c}{\text{min}}\quad c𝑐\displaystyle c (30)
s.t. Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2≤c,∀m∈ℳs,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2𝑐for-all𝑚superscriptℳs\displaystyle\frac{K_{m}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}}\leq c,\forall m\in{\cal M}^{\text{s}}, (31)
‖𝐟‖=1.norm𝐟1\displaystyle\|\mathbf{f}\|=1. (32)

Let 𝐟~≜c​𝐟≜~𝐟𝑐𝐟\tilde{{\bf f}}\triangleq\sqrt{c}\mathbf{f}. We can directly optimize 𝐟~~𝐟\tilde{{\bf f}} instead of 𝐟𝐟{\bf f} and c𝑐c separately in problem (30). In this case, constraint (32) can be dropped, and the objective function is replaced by ‖𝐟~‖2superscriptnorm~𝐟2\|\tilde{{\bf f}}\|^{2}. Thus, we further simplify problem (30) and transform it into the following final equivalent problem:

min𝐟~subscript~𝐟\displaystyle\min_{\tilde{{\bf f}}}\ \ ‖𝐟~‖2superscriptnorm~𝐟2\displaystyle\|\tilde{{\bf f}}\|^{2} (33)
s.t. |𝐟~H​𝐡m|2≥Km2,∀m∈ℳs.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsuperscript~𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2for-all𝑚superscriptℳs\displaystyle|\tilde{{\bf f}}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}\geq K_{m}^{2},\forall m\in{\cal M}^{\text{s}}. (34)

After the above transformations, we arrive at our final problem (33) that is in fact equivalent to a single-group downlink multicast beamforming quality-of-service (QoS) problem [21, 22]: The BS transmits a common message to all devices in ℳssuperscriptℳs{\cal M}^{\text{s}} using the multicast beamforming vector 𝐟~~𝐟\tilde{\bf f}, which is optimized to minimize the transmit power while meeting each device’s SNR target. In our problem (33), the SINR target is Km2superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2K_{m}^{2} for each device m𝑚m. The multicast beamforming design problem has been well studied in the literature [21, 23, 22, 24]. It is generally an NP-had problem. Nonetheless, effective and efficient algorithms have been proposed in the literature to find a close-to-optimal solution [22, 24]. We adopt the SCA method to solve problem (33), which is guaranteed to converge to a stationary point [22]. Once 𝐟~~𝐟\tilde{{\bf f}} is obtained, the receive beamforming vector 𝐟𝐟{\bf f} can be readily computed as 𝐟=𝐟~/‖𝐟~‖𝐟~𝐟norm~𝐟\mathbf{f}={\tilde{\mathbf{f}}}/{\|\tilde{\mathbf{f}}\|}.

IV-A2 Greedy Selection of Devices

As shown in the above problem (33), we note that the receiver beamforming optimization essentially is a single-group multicast beamforming problem. Since the receiver beamforming vector is applied to all device channels, the worst received SNR among devices improves if all devices have good channel conditions and similar channel directions. Based on these heuristics, we propose our greedy device selection process in GSDS.

Our GSDS for device selection is a sequential procedure. We denote the set of selected devices in step i𝑖i by ℳissubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖{\cal M}^{s}_{i}, i=1,2,…,M𝑖12…𝑀i=1,2,\ldots,M. In the initial step, GSDS selects the device with the strongest channel condition. That is, ℳ1s={m1:m1=arg⁡max1≤m≤M‖𝐡m‖}subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠1conditional-setsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚1subscript1𝑚𝑀normsubscript𝐡𝑚{\cal M}^{s}_{1}=\{m_{1}:m_{1}=\mathop{\arg\max}_{1\leq m\leq M}\|{\bf h}_{m}\|\}. In each subsequent step, a new device is selected based on a metric and added to the set of selected devices. Therefore, ℳissubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖{\cal M}^{s}_{i} contains i𝑖i devices.

We propose a metric that measures both device channel strength and its correlation to the set of selected devices. Specifically, in step i𝑖i, for each unselected device m∈ℳ\ℳi−1s𝑚\ℳsubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖1m\in{\cal M}\backslash{\cal M}^{s}_{i-1}, we project its channel 𝐡msubscript𝐡𝑚{\bf h}_{m} onto the subspace spanned by the channel vectors of selected devices. That is, denote ℋi−1s≜{𝐡m:m∈ℳi−1s}≜subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑠𝑖1conditional-setsubscript𝐡𝑚𝑚subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖1{\cal H}^{s}_{i-1}\triangleq\{{\bf h}_{m}:m\in{\cal M}^{s}_{i-1}\}, and let Projℋi−1s​(𝐡m)subscriptProjsubscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑠𝑖1subscript𝐡𝑚\text{Proj}_{{\cal H}^{s}_{i-1}}({\bf h}_{m}) denote the projection of 𝐡msubscript𝐡𝑚{\bf h}_{m} onto ℋi−1ssubscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑠𝑖1{\cal H}^{s}_{i-1}. GSDS first computes ‖Projℋi−1s​(𝐡m)‖normsubscriptProjsubscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑠𝑖1subscript𝐡𝑚\|\text{Proj}_{{\cal H}^{s}_{i-1}}({\bf h}_{m})\|, for each m∈ℳ\ℳi−1s𝑚\ℳsubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖1m\in{\cal M}\backslash{\cal M}^{s}_{i-1}. It then selects the device, represented by misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}, as follows

mi=arg⁡maxm∈ℳ\ℳi−1s‖Projℋi−1s​(𝐡m)‖.subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚\ℳsubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖1normsubscriptProjsubscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑠𝑖1subscript𝐡𝑚\displaystyle m_{i}=\mathop{\arg\max}_{m\in{\cal M}\backslash{\cal M}^{s}_{i-1}}\|\text{Proj}_{{\cal H}^{s}_{i-1}}({\bf h}_{m})\|. (35)

The set of selected devices at step i𝑖i is then given by

ℳis=ℳi−1s∪{mi}.subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑖\displaystyle{\cal M}^{s}_{i}={\cal M}^{s}_{i-1}\cup\{m_{i}\}. (36)

Let 𝐬isubscript𝐬𝑖{\bf s}_{i} be the device selection vector corresponding to ℳissubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖{\cal M}^{s}_{i}. Once 𝐬isubscript𝐬𝑖{\bf s}_{i} is obtained, we optimize the receiver beamforming vector 𝐟𝐟{\bf f} to minimize d​(𝐟,𝐬i;ℋ)𝑑𝐟subscript𝐬𝑖ℋd({\bf f},{\bf s}_{i};{\cal H}) as in problem (25) with given 𝐬isubscript𝐬𝑖{\bf s}_{i}, which is to solve problem (28), except ℳssuperscriptℳ𝑠{\cal M}^{s} is replaced by ℳissubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖{\cal M}^{s}_{i}. Following the approach discussed in Section IV.IV-A-IV-A1, we obtain the receiver beamforming vector, denoted by 𝐟isubscript𝐟𝑖\mathbf{f}_{i} and the value of d​(𝐟i,𝐬i;ℋ)𝑑subscript𝐟𝑖subscript𝐬𝑖ℋd(\mathbf{f}_{i},\mathbf{s}_{i};{\cal H}).

After performing all steps i=1,…,M𝑖1…𝑀i=1,\ldots,M, we choose i⋆superscript𝑖⋆i^{\star} as

i⋆=arg⁡min1≤i≤Md​(𝐟i,𝐬i;ℋ),superscript𝑖⋆subscript1𝑖𝑀𝑑subscript𝐟𝑖subscript𝐬𝑖ℋ\displaystyle i^{\star}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{1\leq i\leq M}~{}d({\bf f}_{i},{\bf s}_{i};{\cal H}), (37)

and the set of selected devices ℳi⋆ssubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠superscript𝑖⋆{\cal M}^{s}_{i^{\star}} (and 𝐬i⋆subscript𝐬superscript𝑖⋆{\bf s}_{i^{\star}}) and receiver beamforming 𝐟i⋆subscript𝐟superscript𝑖⋆{\bf f}_{i^{\star}} as the output of GSDS. The detail of GSDS is summarized in Algorithm 1.

IV-A3 Computational Complexity

Algorithm 1 involves obtaining the set of selected devices {ℳis}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠𝑖𝑖1𝑀\{{\cal M}^{s}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{M} and computing the receiver beamforming vector 𝐟isubscript𝐟𝑖{\bf f}_{i}, i=1,…,M𝑖1…𝑀i=1,\ldots,M. For each step i𝑖i, the computational complexity of determining the selected device misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} in (35) is 𝒪​(N​M2)𝒪𝑁superscript𝑀2\mathcal{O}(NM^{2}). Also, the computational complexity of obtaining the receiver beamforming vector 𝐟isubscript𝐟𝑖{\bf f}_{i} using the SCA method is 𝒪​(Imax​min​(M,N)3),𝒪subscript𝐼maxminsuperscript𝑀𝑁3\mathcal{O}(I_{\text{max}}\text{min}(M,N)^{3}), where Imaxsubscript𝐼maxI_{\text{max}} is the maximum number of SCA iterations to reach the convergence threshold. Since there are total M𝑀M steps in order to determine the set of selected devices ℳi⋆ssubscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑠superscript𝑖⋆{\cal M}^{s}_{i^{\star}} via (37), the overall computational complexity of GSDS is 𝒪​(Imax​min​(M,N)3​M+N​M3)𝒪subscript𝐼maxminsuperscript𝑀𝑁3𝑀𝑁superscript𝑀3\mathcal{O}(I_{\text{max}}\text{min}(M,N)^{3}M+NM^{3}).

IV-B Alternating-optimization-based Device Selection and Beamforming (ADSBF) Approach

The computational complexity of the proposed GSDS grows with the number of devices as O​(M3)𝑂superscript𝑀3O(M^{3}), which is relatively high as M𝑀M becomes large. In this section, we propose an algorithm, named Alternating-optimization-based Device Selection and Beamforming (ADSBF), to determine device selection and receiver beamforming with low computational complexity. ADSBF uses an alternating optimization approach to solve problem (25) w.r.t. devices selection 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} and receiver beamforming vector 𝐟𝐟{\bf f} alternatingly. Specifically, ADSBF breaks problem (25) into two subproblems to solve alternatingly: one is the receiver beamforming optimization with given device selection, and the other is device selection under the provided receive beamforming vector. These two subproblems are described below.

IV-B1 Receiver Beamforming Design Given Device Selection 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}

Given the set of selected devices 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s}, the minimization of d​(𝐟,𝐬;ℋ)𝑑𝐟𝐬ℋd({\bf f},{\bf s};{\cal H}) in problem (25) w.r.t. 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is given by

min𝐟subscript𝐟\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{f}} maxm∈ℳs⁡Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2subscript𝑚superscriptℳssuperscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2\displaystyle\max_{m\in{\cal M}^{\text{s}}}\frac{K_{m}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}} (38)
s.t.‖𝐟‖=1.s.t.norm𝐟1\displaystyle\textrm{s.t.}\quad\|\mathbf{f}\|=1. (39)

which is the same as problem (28). Hence, the approach discussed in Section IV.IV-A-IV-A1 for transforming the problem into problem (33) is directly applicable to problem (38). Following this, we can use the same SCA method to obtain a solution to the problem.

IV-B2 Device Selection Design Given Receiver Beamforming 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f}

Given receiver beamforming vector 𝐟𝐟{\bf f}, problem (25) reduces to

min𝐬∈{0,1}Msubscript𝐬superscript01𝑀\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{s}\in\{0,1\}^{M}}\ 4K2​(K−∑m=1Ms​[m]​Km)24superscript𝐾2superscript𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀𝑠delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝐾𝑚2\displaystyle\frac{4}{K^{2}}(K-\sum_{m=1}^{M}s[m]K_{m})^{2}
+σn2P0​(∑m=1Ms​[m]​Km)2​max1≤m≤M⁡s​[m]​Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2.superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2subscript𝑃0superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀𝑠delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝐾𝑚2subscript1𝑚𝑀𝑠delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2\displaystyle+\frac{\sigma_{n}^{2}}{P_{0}(\sum_{m=1}^{M}s[m]K_{m})^{2}}\max_{1\leq m\leq M}\frac{s[m]K_{m}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}}. (40)

The above problem is an integer program, and it also contains a min-max optimization problem, which typically is hard to solve. However, for this problem, we are able to develop an efficient algorithm to solve it.

Specifically, we first sort {Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2}superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2\big{\{}\frac{K_{m}^{2}}{|{\bf f}^{H}{\bf h}_{m}|^{2}}\big{\}} in ascending order and index the corresponding devices as m1,⋯,mMsubscript𝑚1⋯subscript𝑚𝑀m_{1},\cdots,m_{M}:

Km12|𝐟H​𝐡m1|2≤Km22|𝐟H​𝐡m2|2≤…≤KmM2|𝐟H​𝐡mM|2.superscriptsubscript𝐾subscript𝑚12superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡subscript𝑚12superscriptsubscript𝐾subscript𝑚22superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡subscript𝑚22…superscriptsubscript𝐾subscript𝑚𝑀2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡subscript𝑚𝑀2\displaystyle\frac{K_{m_{1}}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m_{1}}|^{2}}\leq\frac{K_{m_{2}}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m_{2}}|^{2}}\leq...\leq\frac{K_{m_{M}}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m_{M}}|^{2}}. (41)

Let c≜max1≤m≤M⁡s​[m]​Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2≜𝑐subscript1𝑚𝑀𝑠delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2c\triangleq\max_{1\leq m\leq M}\frac{s[m]K_{m}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}}, which is attained by some mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j}, for 1≤j≤M1𝑗𝑀1\leq j\leq M. This means that s​[mj′]=0𝑠delimited-[]subscript𝑚superscript𝑗′0s[m_{j^{\prime}}]=0, j′>jsuperscript𝑗′𝑗j^{\prime}>j, and only the first j𝑗j sorted devices, m1,…,mjsubscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑗m_{1},\ldots,m_{j}, are candidates for selection, and the rest are not selected. Next, for fixed c𝑐c, note that the objective function in (IV-B2) decreases as more devices from {m1,…,mj}subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑗\{m_{1},\ldots,m_{j}\} are selected. As a result, the minimum objective value is attained by selecting all these devices, m1,…,mjsubscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑗m_{1},\ldots,m_{j}.

Therefore, let 𝐳jsubscript𝐳𝑗\mathbf{z}_{j}, 1≤j≤M1𝑗𝑀1\leq j\leq M, denote the device selection vector that selects devices m1,…,mjsubscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑗m_{1},\ldots,m_{j}, given by

𝐳j​[m]={1,for ​m∈{m1,…,mj}0,otherwise.subscript𝐳𝑗delimited-[]𝑚cases1for 𝑚subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑗0otherwise\displaystyle\mathbf{z}_{j}[m]=\begin{cases}1,&\text{for }m\in\{m_{1},\ldots,m_{j}\}\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} (42)

We evaluate the objective function value d​(𝐟,𝐳j;ℋ)𝑑𝐟subscript𝐳𝑗ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{z}_{j};{\cal H}) under each device selection vector 𝐳jsubscript𝐳𝑗{\bf z}_{j}, for j=1,…,M𝑗1…𝑀j=1,\ldots,M. Then, we obtain the optimal selection vector 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} from {𝐳j}subscript𝐳𝑗\{\mathbf{z}_{j}\} that achieves the minimum value among all d​(𝐟,𝐳j;ℋ)𝑑𝐟subscript𝐳𝑗ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{z}_{j};{\cal H})’s:

j⋆superscript𝑗⋆\displaystyle j^{\star} =argmin1≤j≤M​d​(𝐟,𝐳j;ℋ),absent1𝑗𝑀argmin𝑑𝐟subscript𝐳𝑗ℋ\displaystyle=\underset{1\leq j\leq M}{\text{argmin}}\>d(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{z}_{j};{\cal H}), (43)
𝐬𝐬\displaystyle\mathbf{s} =𝐳j⋆.absentsubscript𝐳superscript𝑗⋆\displaystyle=\mathbf{z}_{j^{\star}}. (44)

We summarize the device selection algorithm in Algorithm 2. Below, we show that our proposed algorithm is guaranteed to find the optimal solution 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} to problem (IV-B2).

Proposition 1.

Algorithm 2 produces a global optimal point for problem (IV-B2).

Proof:

Assume 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} is an arbitrary device selection vector. Let m†superscript𝑚†m^{\dagger} be the device with the largest value of Km2|𝐟H​𝐡m|2superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑚2superscriptsuperscript𝐟𝐻subscript𝐡𝑚2\frac{K_{m}^{2}}{|\mathbf{f}^{H}\mathbf{h}_{m}|^{2}} among the selected devices in 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}. Assume its corresponding index in the sorted devices {m1,…,mM}subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑀\{m_{1},\ldots,m_{M}\} in Algorithm 2 is mj†subscript𝑚superscript𝑗†m_{j^{\dagger}} (i.e., m†=mj†superscript𝑚†subscript𝑚superscript𝑗†m^{\dagger}=m_{j^{\dagger}}). Then, the set of selected devices in 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} is a subset of {m1,m2,…,mj†}subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2…subscript𝑚superscript𝑗†\{m_{1},m_{2},...,m_{j^{\dagger}}\}, i.e., the devices selected in 𝐳j†subscript𝐳superscript𝑗†{\bf z}_{j^{\dagger}} defined by Algorithm 2. From the objective function in (IV-B2), we have d​(𝐟,𝐳j†;ℋ)≤d​(𝐟,𝐲;ℋ)𝑑𝐟subscript𝐳superscript𝑗†ℋ𝑑𝐟𝐲ℋd(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{z}_{j^{\dagger}};{\cal H})\leq d(\mathbf{f},\mathbf{y};{\cal H}). Thus, for ∀𝐲∈{0,1}Mfor-all𝐲superscript01𝑀\forall{\bf y}\in\{0,1\}^{M}, we can find a selection vector in {𝐳j}subscript𝐳𝑗\{{\bf z}_{j}\} with an equal or less objective value. Thus, the global optimal point is in {𝐳j}subscript𝐳𝑗\{{\bf z}_{j}\}. ∎

Our proposed ADSBF alternatingly solve the two subproblems w.r.t. 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} and 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} described in Sections IV.IV-B.IV-B1 and IV.IV-B.IV-B2, respectively, to obtain a solution to problem (25). The overall ADSBF algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 3.

IV-B3 Initialization and Convergence

Note that the SCA method used for the receiver beamforming subproblem requires a feasible initial point to problem (33). At the initial iteration l=1𝑙1l=1, this initial point can be found by solving problem (33) using the semi-definite relaxation (SDR) approach [22], which gives a feasible approximate solution. In the subsequent iteration l>1𝑙1l>1, the receive beamforming vector 𝐟(l−1)superscript𝐟𝑙1{\bf f}^{(l-1)} obtained from the previous iteration (l−1)𝑙1(l-1) is used as the initial point for the SCA method in this iteration l𝑙l. Since the SCA is guaranteed to converge to a local minimum, and the device selection subproblem is solved optimally, the objective value in (25) is non-increasing over iterations and is non-negative. Thus, ADSBF is guaranteed to converge.

IV-B4 Computational Complexity

The computational complexity of Algorithm 2 is 𝒪​(M2+M​N)𝒪superscript𝑀2𝑀𝑁\mathcal{O}(M^{2}+MN), and that for solving problem (33) by the SCA method is 𝒪(Imaxmin(N,M)3)\mathcal{O}(I_{\text{max}}\min(N,M)^{3}), where Imaxsubscript𝐼maxI_{\text{max}} is the number of SCA iterations. Therefore, the overall computational complexity of ADSBF is 𝒪(Jmax(Imaxmin(N,M)3+M2+MN)),{\cal O}(J_{\text{max}}(I_{\text{max}}\min(N,M)^{3}+M^{2}+MN)), where Jmaxsubscript𝐽maxJ_{\text{max}} is the maximum number of iterations of ADSBF.

V Simulation Results

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our proposed approaches for an image classification task. We consider training and testing using the logistic regression for the MNIST [25] dataset and the convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for the CIFAR-101010 [26] dataset.

We consider a scenario with M=200𝑀200M=200 devices and N=16𝑁16N=16 antennas. The distance between each device m𝑚m and the parameter server, denoted by dmsubscript𝑑𝑚d_{m}, is drawn from a uniform distribution: dm∼U​[rmin,rmax]similar-tosubscript𝑑𝑚𝑈subscript𝑟minsubscript𝑟maxd_{m}\sim U[r_{\text{min}},r_{\text{max}}], where rmin=10​msubscript𝑟min10mr_{\text{min}}=10~{}\text{m} and rmax=100​msubscript𝑟max100mr_{\text{max}}=100~{}\text{m}. The path loss follows the COST Hata model, given by PL[dB]=139.1+35.22​log​(dm​[km])PL[dB]139.135.22logsubscript𝑑𝑚delimited-[]km\text{PL[dB]}=139.1+35.22\>\text{log}(d_{m}[\text{km}]). We assume the device channels are constant during the training. The channel vector for device m𝑚m is generated using a complex Gaussian distribution as 𝐡m,t=𝐡m∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,1P​L​𝐈N),∀tformulae-sequencesubscript𝐡𝑚𝑡subscript𝐡𝑚similar-to𝒞𝒩01𝑃𝐿subscript𝐈𝑁for-all𝑡\mathbf{h}_{m,t}=\mathbf{h}_{m}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\frac{1}{PL}\mathbf{I}_{N}),\forall t. The maximum permissible average transmit power for the devices is assumed to be P0=0subscript𝑃00P_{0}=0 dBm. For comparison, we also consider the following approaches:

  1. 1.

    Select all: All of the devices are selected to contribute to the FL training, i.e., ℳs=ℳsuperscriptℳ𝑠ℳ\mathcal{M}^{s}=\mathcal{M}. The receive beamforming is obtained by solving problem (28) via the SCA method.

  2. 2.

    Top one: Only the device with the strongest channel condition is selected to contribute to the FL training, i.e., ℳs={m†}superscriptℳ𝑠superscript𝑚†\mathcal{M}^{s}=\{m^{\dagger}\}, where m†=arg⁡min1≤m≤M⁡‖𝐡m‖superscript𝑚†subscript1𝑚𝑀normsubscript𝐡𝑚m^{\dagger}=\arg\min_{1\leq m\leq M}\>\|\mathbf{h}_{m}\|. The receiver beamforming vector is aligned with the channel vector of the selected device, i.e., 𝐟=𝐡m†/‖𝐡m†‖𝐟subscript𝐡superscript𝑚†normsubscript𝐡superscript𝑚†\mathbf{f}={\mathbf{h}_{m^{\dagger}}}/{\|\mathbf{h}_{m^{\dagger}}\|}.

  3. 3.

    Gibbs sampling [18]: Gibbs sampling is used for device selection, and the receiver beamforming vector is obtained by an SCA method.

  4. 4.

    DC approach [16]: The receiver beamforming and the device selection are jointly optimized by DC programming to maximize the number of selected devices, subject to the MSE of the over-the-air aggregation for the global model is no larger than threshold γ𝛾\gamma.

Note that for a fair comparison of the computational complexity, the SCA method described in Section IV.IV-A.IV-A1 is used in GSDS, ADSBF, select all, and Gibbs sampling methods. The maximum number of iterations for ADSBF is set to Jmax=10subscript𝐽max10J_{\text{max}}=10. For the Gibbs sampling method, to achieve the optimal performance, we set the initial temperature β0=1subscript𝛽01\beta_{0}=1, and the cooling schedule parameter ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1. Additionally, the number of iterations is configured to be 404040. It is important to note that these parameter values have been determined through hyper-parameter tuning. For DC approach, the parameter γ𝛾\gamma must be carefully tuned to ensure that an appropriate number of devices are selected to attain the optimal performance. After conducting the hyper-parameter tuning, we set γ=94𝛾94\gamma=94 dB to achieve the fastest training convergence. Note that since the channel conditions in our experiments are much weaker than that of [16], the resulting MSE is larger, and hence we need to set γ𝛾\gamma to a larger value compared to [16]. In contrast to Gibbs sampling and DC approach, our proposed GSDS and ADSBF do not require extra hyperparameter tuning. This is a noticeable advantage, as our proposed methods do not need extensive tuning.

V-A MNIST Dataset

In the MNIST dataset, each individual data sample is a labeled gray-scale image of 28×28282828\times 28 pixels, depicting a handwritten digit, denoted by 𝐱k∈ℝ784subscript𝐱𝑘superscriptℝ784\mathbf{x}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{784}. The corresponding label, yk∈{0,1,…,9}subscript𝑦𝑘01…9y_{k}\in\{0,1,...,9\}, specifies the class to which the image belongs. The dataset consists of 60,0006000060,000 training samples and 10,0001000010,000 test samples, belonging to ten different classes. We consider training a multinomial logistic regression classifier with the cross-entropy loss function given by

l​(𝐰;𝐱k,yk)=−∑j=091​{yk=j}​log​exp​(𝐮kT​𝐰(j))∑i=09exp​(𝐮kT​𝐰(i)),𝑙𝐰subscript𝐱𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗091subscript𝑦𝑘𝑗logexpsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑘𝑇superscript𝐰𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖09expsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑘𝑇superscript𝐰𝑖\displaystyle l(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{k},y_{k})=-\sum\limits_{j=0}^{9}1\{y_{k}=j\}\text{log}\frac{\text{exp}(\mathbf{u}_{k}^{T}\mathbf{w}^{(j)})}{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{9}\text{exp}(\mathbf{u}_{k}^{T}\mathbf{w}^{(i)})}, (45)

where 1​{⋅}1⋅1\{\cdot\} is an indicator function, 𝐮k=[𝐱kT,1]Tsubscript𝐮𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑇1𝑇{\bf u}_{k}=[\mathbf{x}_{k}^{T},1]^{T}, and 𝐰=[𝐰(0)T,…,𝐰(9)T]T𝐰superscriptsuperscriptsuperscript𝐰0𝑇…superscriptsuperscript𝐰9𝑇𝑇\mathbf{w}=[{\mathbf{w}^{(0)}}^{T},\ldots,{\mathbf{w}^{(9)}}^{T}]^{T} with 𝐰(j)∈ℝ785superscript𝐰𝑗superscriptℝ785{\bf w}^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{785} being the model parameter vector for class j𝑗j, consisting of 784 weights and a bias term.

We assume the data distribution over devices is i.i.d. Each device’s local dataset contains an equal number of data samples from different classes, and the number of local data samples in each device is Km=270subscript𝐾𝑚270K_{m}=270. Upon thorough hyperparameter tuning, we set a unified learning rate λ=0.05𝜆0.05\lambda=0.05 for the global model update in (3) for all approaches. Furthermore, the full local batch is used for the gradient computation in each communication round for all approaches. A (training) epoch refers to one training pass over the entire training dataset by all devices. Since the devices are using the full local batch in this setting, each epoch only consists of a single communication round. Finally, we set the receiver noise power σn2=−20superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛220\sigma_{n}^{2}=-20 dBm, which generally includes both receiver thermal noise and interference signals.

Figs. 3 and 3 respectively show the average test accuracy and the average test loss with 95%percent9595\% confidence intervals over the 202020 different channel realizations and receiver noise realizations. We see from both figures that our proposed GSDS and ADSBF approaches converge after T=100𝑇100T=100 rounds, which is the fastest convergence rate among all the considered methods. Also, they achieve the highest test accuracy and lowest test loss among the approaches considered. This demonstrates the efficacy of our proposed methods for device selection. Between ADSBF and GSDS, although ADSBF performs slightly worse than GSDS, its run time is significantly lower than that of GSDS as discussed below. Note that due to high instability, the loss of DC approach is significantly larger than the rest approaches, and we omit to show the test loss of this approach in Fig. 3.

Fig. 4 shows the average number of selected devices by different approaches over 202020 channel realizations. The accompanying error bar indicates the standard deviation around the average value. We see that ADSBF and GSDS select fewer devices than Gibbs sampling and DC approaches, but more than Top one. This result, combined with the learning performance results in Figs. 3 and 3, demonstrates the effectiveness of our methods in providing a proper trade-off between imperfect noisy communication and the amount of training data provided by the local devices for model training through device selection.

Table II lists the average computation time of generating the beamforming and device selection solution using different approaches prior to the start of training. As we see in the column of the MNIST dataset, our proposed GSDS and ADSBF have significantly lower computational complexity as compared with the Gibbs sampling and DC approach. Furthermore, we see that the run time of ADSBF is two magnitudes lower than that of GSDS, with a slightly worse test accuracy. This demonstrates the computational advantage of ADSBF over GSDS and the overall efficacy of ADSBF.

V-B CIFAR-10 Dataset

For the CIFAR-10 dataset, each individual data sample is a colored image of 3×32×32332323\times 32\times 32 pixels, which is represented as 𝐱k∈ℝ3×ℝ32×ℝ32subscript𝐱𝑘superscriptℝ3superscriptℝ32superscriptℝ32\mathbf{x}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}\times\mathbb{R}^{32}\times\mathbb{R}^{32}; the associated label yk∈{0,1,…,9}subscript𝑦𝑘01…9y_{k}\in\{0,1,...,9\} indicates the image’s corresponding class. The dataset comprises a total of 50,0005000050,000 training samples and 10,0001000010,000 test samples. Given the increased complexity of this dataset, we opt for a more sophisticated convolutional neural network (CNN) model: the Residual Network (ResNet) with 14 layers (ResNet-14) [27]. The training process employs the cross-entropy loss function. To enhance the training process, we implement a data augmentation technique outlined in [27]. This technique involves augmenting the data by adding a 4-pixel padding on all sides and randomly selecting a 32×32323232\times 32 crop from either the padded image or its horizontally flipped counterpart.

Note that our joint optimization problem (25) is obtained based on the training convergence analysis under Assumptions A1-A4 with a strongly convex loss function, which is not the case here due to the non-convex nature of CNNs. Nonetheless, we test our proposed approaches using this dataset to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method for this application.

Following the approach similar to that for the MNIST dataset, we uniformly allocate the training samples of each class across the devices, with a total number of samples per device as Km=250subscript𝐾𝑚250K_{m}=250. During each communication round, the devices compute their local gradient by processing a batch of 50 data samples from their respective local datasets. Consequently, each epoch comprises 5 communication rounds, and we assess the model’s accuracy upon the completion of each epoch. We use the built-in SGD optimizer in PyTorch [28] and set the value of the learning rate as 0.010.010.01, the value of momentum as 0.90.90.9, and the value of weight decay factor as 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. We set the receiver noise power σn2=−50superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛250\sigma_{n}^{2}=-50 dBm.

Figs.  6 and 6 show the average test accuracy and average test loss, along with 95%percent9595\% confidence intervals, across 202020 different channel and communication noise realizations. Again, we see that our proposed GSDS and ADSBF consistently achieve superior test accuracy and lower test loss after 400400400 epochs as compared to other approaches. Note that we omit showing the loss values for the Top one and DC approach in Fig. 6 as these methods result in a very large test loss due to their low accuracy as shown in Fig. 6.

The beamforming and device selection computation time for each approach, prior to the start of training for the ResNet model, is listed in the last column of Table II. Similar to that of the MNIST dataset, our proposed methods have significantly lower computational complexity than the Gibbs sampling and DC approaches.

Fig. 7 shows the average number of selected devices and the standard deviation over 20 channel realizations obtained by different approaches. Similar to the experiments with MNIST dataset, we see that ADSBF and GSDS select fewer devices than Gibbs sampling, but more than DC and Top one approaches. This again shows the effectiveness of our methods in choosing an appropriate set of devices to trade off communication imperfection and the amount of training data from devices to achieve a satisfactory learning performance.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we have jointly designed uplink receiver beamforming and device selection in over-the-air FL to minimize the global training loss after arbitrary T𝑇T communication rounds, assuming time-varying wireless channels. To tackle this challenging stochastic optimization problem, we have obtained an upper bound for the global training loss and designed receiver beamforming and device selection to minimize this upper bound. We have proposed two approaches, GSDS and ADSBF, to obtain a solution. GSDS uses a greedy method that exploits the channel strength and correlation to sequentially add devices to the set of selected devices. In contrast, ADSBF employs the alternating optimization technique to solve the device selection and receiver beamforming subproblems alternatingly, where we have provided an efficient algorithm to solve the device selection subproblem optimally with low computational complexity. In both approaches, we have shown that given the selected devices, the receiver beamforming optimization problem is equivalent to downlink single-group multicast beamforming, for which existing efficient algorithms can be used to obtain a solution. The simulation results obtained from image classification experiments have demonstrated that both GSDS and ADSBF speed up the training convergence and have lower computational complexity than the state-of-the-art approaches. Furthermore, we have observed that GSDS and ADSBF offer two distinct design choices with a trade-off between learning performance and computational complexity.
